title: Episode 109 â€“ Dr. Robert Cloninger, MD, PhD, Genetics & Psychology of Stewardship, Happiness, & Hope
subtitle: Sarah Arao Mantle of Hope- Thank You Video to the Y on Earth Community for GoFundMe Campaign Support
full_transcript:
[9.6s - 16.2s]: Welcome to the Y on Earth Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry. And today,

[16.4s - 22.8s]: we're visiting with Dr. Robert Klonenger. Hey Robert. Hey, good to see you here. Good to see you too.

[23.6s - 27.1s]: I'm so excited about our conversation today and it's one that I think is

[27.1s - 33.7s]: among the most important we can be having about our reaction and response to some of the great

[33.7s - 38.1s]: challenges we're going through in these times. So I appreciate you taking the time to visit with us,

[38.2s - 45.8s]: Dr. Robert Klonenger. Dr. Robert Klonenger is director of the Anthropedia Institute and Professor

[45.8s - 52.1s]: of Maritus at Washington University in St. Louis. He was Wallace rendered professor of psychiatry,

[52.1s - 57.9s]: Professor of genetics, Professor of psychological and brain sciences, and Director of the San

[57.9s - 63.8s]: Zone Family Center for Wellbeing at Washington University School of Medicine until July 2019.

[65.0s - 69.1s]: The Anthropedia Institute is the research and advisory component of the Anthropedia

[69.1s - 75.6s]: Foundation, a nonprofit organization dedicated to development of human well-being through initiatives

[75.6s - 81.8s]: and healthcare and education. He is widely cited and honored for his innovative biopsychosocial

[81.8s - 89.5s]: research that spans the genetics, neurobiology, development, psychology, brain imaging, and assessment

[89.5s - 96.1s]: of personality and psychopathology. His personality inventories have been used in more than 6,000

[96.1s - 100.9s]: peer-reviewed publications around the world. And he is one of the most highly cited scientists

[100.9s - 105.9s]: in the world across all fields, in fact in the top, one-one-hundredth of a percent.

[107.3s - 112.1s]: He received his bachelor's with high honors and special honors in philosophy, psychology,

[112.2s - 119.0s]: and anthropology from the University of Texas at Austin and received his MD from Washington University

[119.5s - 125.3s]: and an honorary doctorate from the University of New Mea and the University of Gutenberg.

[126.4s - 132.8s]: Dr. Klondinger has published 10 books and over 600 articles in psychiatry, psychology, and genetics.

[133.3s - 138.5s]: His recent books include Feeling Good, The Science of Wellbeing by Oxford University Press,

[139.3s - 146.3s]: Origins of Altruism and Cooperation by Springer, and Personality and Psychopathology by American

[146.3s - 153.1s]: Psychiatric Press. And these many awards you've received, Dr. Klondinger will include in the

[153.1s - 159.9s]: show notes. And clearly you've been not only well recognized by the global community for your work,

[160.2s - 165.9s]: but it's so interesting to note that of the some 17 million scientists around the world who

[165.9s - 171.3s]: have received two or more citations, you're in the top two hundred or something like that,

[171.3s - 177.4s]: around 180, which is really extraordinary. And I'm so excited about our conversation today because

[178.1s - 184.8s]: we're going to do our best to cover your science, which really is avant-garde cutting edge science.

[185.5s - 189.1s]: And translate it and boil it down to many in our audience who are not necessarily

[189.1s - 196.3s]: themselves scientists, let alone neuroscientists or medical professionals. And your research and the

[196.3s - 203.0s]: work you're doing through anthropemia and elsewhere is from my perspective, one of the most important

[203.8s - 209.4s]: leading edges of the kind of work, the healing work, and the creative work we have to do in our

[209.4s - 218.5s]: world right now, given the extraordinary challenges and crises that we're now facing. And so I want

[218.5s - 225.4s]: to open Robert first by thanking you again. And secondly by asking you a very open-ended question,

[226.3s - 232.9s]: from your perspective, with all the research you're doing, what is the most important insight

[233.9s - 237.1s]: you're helping to make known in the world right now?

[238.6s - 246.1s]: You know, we've of course as you emphasize in your work, we face many challenges as a species.

[246.9s - 254.8s]: We're in essentially the sixth grade extinction. And human beings are largely responsible.

[255.4s - 262.2s]: For the impact on the environment that is causing these problems. And so the fundamental questions

[262.2s - 268.7s]: that I've been concerned about is to understand whether what it is about our human nature

[269.7s - 276.9s]: that may have led us to get to this situation, to create this situation. And more importantly,

[277.9s - 284.7s]: understanding who we really are and what it is that's necessary for us to be healthy and happy.

[285.4s - 292.3s]: And to be able to live sustainably. What can we do? What is it that allowed us to become so successful

[292.3s - 301.3s]: in the first place? And what is it that's going wrong? So from that, what I've done is to try to first

[301.3s - 309.5s]: develop measures of who are we? How do we describe our personality and the way we learn and adapt

[309.5s - 317.3s]: to our life? So that's why I developed personality inventories and then tried to validate those

[317.3s - 326.8s]: to show just what it is that makes up a healthy person. And more recently, once we had established

[326.8s - 334.6s]: that we had good ways to measure human health and well-being, the physical, mental, the spiritual,

[335.2s - 342.3s]: social components of health and what gives us satisfaction. Then, well, how did that come to be?

[343.0s - 349.7s]: And what was it that led to the evolution of our capacity to be creative, to be

[350.4s - 359.9s]: pro-social, to look out for our neighbors, to look out for the environment? And that has been

[359.9s - 366.7s]: the task I set for myself. And it's really been a fairly long journey because I started this

[366.7s - 378.5s]: in the mid-80s, 1980. So it's been 36 years that I've been working on this set of problems.

[380.4s - 387.7s]: Yeah, it's tremendous. And obviously in that time, you've covered so much deep and complex

[387.7s - 395.1s]: scientific research. And we're going to include a handful of articles in the show notes that folks can

[395.9s - 402.0s]: go to if they're interested in diving deeper. It includes a relatively recent article,

[402.8s - 407.9s]: the complex genetics and biology of human temperament, a review of traditional concepts in relation

[407.9s - 415.7s]: to the new molecular findings. And I want to get to that in a few minutes. But in preparing for our

[415.7s - 423.7s]: discussion, I was especially struck by a piece that you wrote in 2013 called What Makes People

[423.7s - 431.4s]: Healthy, Happy and Fulfilled in the Face of Current World Challenges. For in this short eight-page

[432.0s - 439.5s]: documents, you do an extraordinary job of summarizing and making very clear and easy to understand

[440.5s - 450.9s]: some critical aspects of ourselves as individual humans. And how that has an impact and influence on

[451.5s - 456.1s]: our complex social interactions as well as our impacts on the planet environmentally speaking.

[456.8s - 462.5s]: And so I wanted to kick it right off by jumping into this discussion where you've identified

[463.1s - 470.7s]: three key attributes, self-directedness, cooperativesness, and self-transcendence as critical to

[470.7s - 477.2s]: understanding perhaps our own individual development and then how we might go about

[477.9s - 480.8s]: fomenting more positive change in our world.

[481.9s - 490.3s]: Okay. Well, it'll help me to summarize those. Okay. I think the key notion for people to get

[490.9s - 500.4s]: is that human personality actually involves two domains. One is our temperament, which are simply

[500.4s - 509.6s]: our emotional drives like to look out for danger, which I call harmit winds, to be interested in things

[509.6s - 520.2s]: that are unusual, new, complex, which I call novelly seeking. And also to be sensitive to what other

[520.2s - 527.7s]: people are feeling in reaction to our behavior, which I call sociability or reward dependence,

[528.0s - 537.8s]: because we're very sensitive to the cues that people give us. These are traits that actually

[537.8s - 547.0s]: involve the way we learn from very in response to very simple stimuli. And it's not a rational

[547.0s - 554.9s]: process. These are what create our habits and our attachments and our desires, which are often

[554.9s - 565.7s]: irrational. And so, but this is our emotional style. Now, we are different from chimpanzees and our

[565.7s - 574.2s]: other ancestors, because although we share temperament, we have evolved to other systems of learning

[574.2s - 582.1s]: and memory that give us an ability to control our emotions, to regulate them,

[583.7s - 594.0s]: intentionally to achieve goals. And a second system for being self-aware and being able to

[595.3s - 605.0s]: use our awareness to consider the value that achieving a goal may have for our life and our

[605.0s - 611.0s]: satisfaction. And one impact it might have on other people and on the planet in which we live.

[612.8s - 623.1s]: And so, what happens in life is for us to learn how to regulate our emotions and our habits and

[623.1s - 632.5s]: our attachments and desires to be consistent with goals that are rational. And in addition,

[633.0s - 639.6s]: that have a value that's long term for ourselves and others so that in a sense they're good.

[640.3s - 647.3s]: If we make our habits consistent with our goals and our values, then we can have a life that is

[647.3s - 654.3s]: both healthy, physically, and happy, emotionally, and also has meaning and purpose.

[656.1s - 666.4s]: And so, self-directedness and cooperatives are the two characteristics that mature humans have.

[666.8s - 671.8s]: We all have the capacity for these, but not everyone because of their life circumstances or other

[671.8s - 677.0s]: things develop it. But if you're self-directed, that means that you're

[677.8s - 684.8s]: purposeful and resourceful, and you're also willing to take responsibility to get things done.

[685.3s - 692.5s]: If you're cooperative, you're tolerant and helpful and empathic, and you'll at least do things

[692.5s - 697.8s]: that are of mutual benefit for yourself and other people. You look for win solutions.

[698.7s - 706.2s]: So that's our system for intentional self-control. And then there's a third system that is also a

[706.2s - 713.3s]: part of character, and that is this creative self-awareness that I've mentioned. And that is also,

[713.5s - 721.6s]: that is expressed, it is expressed, we are both self-directed and cooperative, but we add to what

[721.6s - 732.2s]: you see with just logical reasoning and analysis. We add to it a sense of compassion and love and

[732.2s - 740.7s]: hope and faith, when fully developed. And so the difference between people who are simply regulating

[740.7s - 750.8s]: their habits to make money and achieve goals and maybe be famous, the difference between that

[750.8s - 758.5s]: self-interested way of living and developing self-awareness of your relationship to other people

[758.5s - 765.8s]: and the planet, the world in general, is self-transcendence. So the difference between being self-interested

[765.8s - 774.8s]: and self-transcendent is actually critical in current time. And what I found was that people were only

[775.5s - 782.5s]: self-directed and cooperative, but not self-transcendent. Then they would take pretty good care of themselves

[782.5s - 790.2s]: and those who were close to them, but they might just ignore the needs of the community as a whole

[790.2s - 794.6s]: in the planet. And so they wouldn't be concerned about equity, sustainability,

[794.6s - 805.5s]: and basic principles of fairness and so on. The people who were self-transcendent instead of

[805.5s - 814.6s]: simply self-interested were really more characteristic or younger generation who are not satisfied with

[814.6s - 822.2s]: materialistic values and executive control. They are more interested, they're post-materialists,

[822.2s - 828.6s]: we're sometimes called culturally creative. They have a creative character in which they have

[828.6s - 835.1s]: humanitarian interests, ecological intelligence, social intelligence and so on, because they want

[835.1s - 840.5s]: to try to help us live in harmony with one another in the planet, in which we share.

[842.3s - 848.7s]: And so this actually goes back to a very longstanding debate about what is a healthy personality.

[849.6s - 855.6s]: And in the West we've tended to think that a healthy personality was just being self-directed and

[855.6s - 862.2s]: cooperative. And that does pretty well for most of people's lives, but by the time you get in your

[862.2s - 868.3s]: thirties and by the time you get in your forties and fifties, most people in Western societies who

[868.3s - 876.5s]: have that style of living start getting multiple diseases. And they begin to question whether their

[876.5s - 882.6s]: values are really satisfying because they thought that if they achieved money and power and so on,

[882.6s - 889.3s]: that they would be fulfilled and satisfied. But look around at the wealthiest executives and people

[889.3s - 894.4s]: with a lot of influence and they're often still very unsatisfied with their lives and they feel

[894.4s - 900.2s]: something's missing. And that's something that's missing is really this need for us to

[901.1s - 909.6s]: do the kinds of things in our life that will awaken us to our connections with one another in the

[909.6s - 918.2s]: planet. This feeling, it's not just wishful thinking or opinion to think that we're an integral

[918.2s - 926.8s]: part of the world and inseparable from one another. It's actually the truth that the world operates

[927.3s - 933.8s]: not less with competition and with symbiosis and we're connected. And most of us,

[934.0s - 939.5s]: three-fourths of people actually have these self-transcendent experiences where they feel at least

[939.5s - 946.3s]: briefly at times in their life under good conditions connected to one another and they feel

[946.3s - 953.3s]: connected to the universe at times. They have moments of joy like that. But it's very difficult in

[953.3s - 963.3s]: modern society to sustain that from day to day. And as a result, we're manipulated by all the

[963.3s - 971.1s]: signals and social media to grab our attention to looking for likes or making more money or

[971.1s - 977.7s]: consuming more or having the newest car and things like that that actually are leading us to

[979.6s - 986.2s]: deplete the ecological resources of the earth to a point that since the mid-70s, the earth has

[986.2s - 993.9s]: not been able to restore its ecological health. And so we're gradually step-by-step degrading the

[993.9s - 1005.2s]: environment that we need. So I ask myself, what can we do to have people realize that they're not

[1005.2s - 1012.4s]: currently, most of us are not living in a court with our human nature. But because there's a lot

[1012.4s - 1019.0s]: of controversy in science and society about what is the healthy personality, I had to really look

[1019.0s - 1024.8s]: for objective science to see what's the truth here. Is it really just the people who are self-interested

[1024.8s - 1033.7s]: that are the natural human? And this other is kind of a fantasy for humanists and a few people who

[1033.7s - 1041.8s]: are very spiritually or religiously oriented. And what I discovered here, and I think may not surprise

[1041.8s - 1048.7s]: you, but it surprised a lot of my colleagues. We set out to identify all the genes for human

[1048.7s - 1053.9s]: personality. We found that there are about a thousand of them and they interact with each other

[1053.9s - 1059.8s]: in very complex ways. And it turns out that what distinguishes us from

[1061.4s - 1067.1s]: chimpanzees and even from the endotholes is this capacity for self-transcendence.

[1068.4s - 1075.0s]: That's what gave us the creativity and the ability to appreciate our need to work effectively in

[1075.0s - 1080.9s]: cooperative communities. And that's what led us to be able to displace all the other

[1081.8s - 1088.0s]: hominids, the early humans on earth. Because if you work in social groups, you look out for your

[1088.0s - 1093.6s]: children, your grandchildren, and even strangers in your community, it turns out that that's a very

[1093.6s - 1100.5s]: powerful force. And our capacity for being inventive and creative rather than just, you know,

[1101.1s - 1109.4s]: being selfish and looking for using our power to do things that will serve us, we can have a vision

[1109.4s - 1114.9s]: and imagination of the future that's healthy for us. And it turns out that that

[1115.8s - 1121.3s]: set that character, that creative character, who self-directed the cooperative and self-transcendence

[1122.9s - 1131.4s]: has much more energy is physically more resilient to injury and aging and all sorts of toxicity

[1131.4s - 1141.9s]: that, you know, abounds in the world today and that we're happier and we're able to be much more

[1141.9s - 1149.5s]: adaptive and innovate when faced with the kinds of challenges. And it turned out that, you know,

[1149.7s - 1155.8s]: despite all the things that we're doing, wrong now that are decreasing the sustainability of

[1155.8s - 1161.3s]: the environment which we live, it turns out that we actually evolved, became human, but

[1161.3s - 1167.6s]: modern humans with creativity in the sense of community and an imagination for how to get along

[1167.6s - 1174.3s]: with each other. That happened in response to climatic changes that were threatening our very

[1174.3s - 1180.2s]: survival. That was that started about three or four hundred thousand years ago.

[1182.6s - 1191.4s]: And the system for temperament and social agreement, that goes back 40 million years.

[1192.0s - 1199.3s]: The capacity for logical analysis and just being self-directed and, you know, making good tools

[1199.3s - 1206.4s]: and so on, that goes back about two million years. But the capacity to be creative in communal

[1206.4s - 1212.4s]: and self-transcendent goes back only a hundred thousand years. And it's within that time that we

[1212.4s - 1220.3s]: actually became dominant on the earth. But in the last two or three hundred years, as we moved into

[1220.3s - 1225.2s]: our industrial society, we lost track of the very thing that made us so successful.

[1226.7s - 1235.2s]: And we became very concerned with our power and domination over the earth until we realized

[1235.2s - 1243.9s]: it is not an inexhaustible resource. And we lost a lot of our sense of need for social equity.

[1243.9s - 1252.5s]: Yeah. And I need to use creativity. So I'm sorry. You got me going on a lot of important issues.

[1252.6s - 1259.1s]: But I hope I answered the question in context. Very, very much so. And it's appreciated.

[1260.0s - 1268.7s]: And makes sense. I have a follow on question, which is we can clearly trace some of the

[1269.6s - 1278.6s]: roots of our current psychospiritual and social challenges back to the dawn of what we call

[1279.3s - 1285.2s]: civilization. A lot of work's been done in the area of eco psychology and elsewhere too. So

[1285.8s - 1292.5s]: and I don't think it's by any means a stretch to say in the 20th century in particular,

[1293.0s - 1299.4s]: there has been this hyper acceleration of this ultra individualism,

[1299.6s - 1308.1s]: you know, sort of the Gordon Gecko greed is good. The iron ran cult of individualism called

[1309.2s - 1315.2s]: you know, positive objectivism in stories like Atlas shrugged, which is one of the most

[1315.2s - 1323.8s]: red books ever. And we've basically many of us grown up in and only really experienced,

[1323.8s - 1331.1s]: especially in the West, especially in the United States. A culture that is so infused with

[1331.1s - 1340.2s]: and permeated with an ethos stemming from a super underdeveloped self transcendence in the

[1340.2s - 1350.3s]: leadership. It strikes me that this is a really important thing for us to understand. And I'm also

[1350.3s - 1356.6s]: curious if you could expand on the observation you make in the paper that many, if not most, of the

[1356.6s - 1361.2s]: corporate leaders over the last several decades and political leaders and others who are really

[1361.2s - 1369.6s]: making the major decisions in the world up to this point, generally have underdeveloped self

[1369.6s - 1376.2s]: transcendence attributes. And can you tell us a bit about the science how you go about realizing

[1376.2s - 1384.0s]: that kind of thing? And then also what you think that means in terms of strategies and approaches,

[1384.0s - 1387.9s]: we might be taking going forward to help remedy that fact.

[1388.7s - 1394.7s]: Well, there are several very important questions. There are several parts of this. First,

[1395.5s - 1404.3s]: the fact is that the current sort of business philosophy that emphasizes profit without a sense

[1404.3s - 1412.7s]: of social responsibility and that thinks like Hayek said that social justice is just an illusion.

[1413.6s - 1422.1s]: And it's a fiction is simply not consistent with our human nature. It's simply not true because

[1422.1s - 1432.0s]: we can show that what made us homo sapiens wise and virtuous is the recognition of our connectedness,

[1432.4s - 1439.2s]: not our separateness. So if you have an attitude that you're separate, you're going to be defensive

[1439.2s - 1446.5s]: and competitive and it tends to lead to insatiable desire for power and money and so on.

[1447.1s - 1449.9s]: And it turns out that that just never satisfies. I mean,

[1451.7s - 1460.2s]: and then the fact is that what makes us work to be physically, mentally and socially,

[1461.0s - 1470.0s]: healthy is to really identify as a part of something larger than our individual self.

[1470.6s - 1476.3s]: And that's what self transcendent means is that you're willing to make sacrifices for others

[1476.3s - 1483.4s]: and to work for harmony rather than competition because you really feel you're part of one whole.

[1485.3s - 1490.0s]: And that's the reality. I mean, if you think about it, we never we don't live in a vacuum. We are not

[1490.0s - 1499.3s]: really separate. We have so many bacteria in our microbiome that are really a part of us. We're

[1499.3s - 1507.9s]: share the air that each of us breathes, the land, the planet. And so we're all a part of this larger

[1507.9s - 1517.9s]: hole and we have to be stewards of that. Now, what's remarkable is that there's so many things going on

[1518.7s - 1523.9s]: now that are leading us to not use the self awareness that will fully capable of.

[1524.9s - 1534.3s]: So, you know, having the notification signals on your iPhone that constantly grabbing your attention

[1535.7s - 1542.4s]: actually keeps you responding by habit. It's an addiction. And when you get

[1543.2s - 1552.1s]: controlled by that, then you can't enjoy silence. You can't be aware effectively of being

[1552.1s - 1558.9s]: a participant in a larger hole. So we need to spend more time with our iPhones off,

[1559.8s - 1566.1s]: you know, in nature walks or gardening or in true dialogue with someone where you're

[1567.0s - 1572.4s]: looking at each other's eyes and you're thinking about what's he feeling? Why is he thinking that?

[1572.6s - 1577.6s]: Why does he think differently than me? I mean, because we are each born with different talents,

[1578.4s - 1585.4s]: strengths and weaknesses. Nobody's perfect. But together, if we work cooperatively, we create a very

[1585.4s - 1593.8s]: resilient community and planet. And so it's getting to let ourselves have the experience

[1593.8s - 1599.7s]: so we can judge for ourselves what's healthy and satisfying for me. Not someone telling me how

[1599.7s - 1605.7s]: to live my life. We need freedom. We need flexibility. We don't need to be controlled. But we're

[1606.0s - 1614.1s]: actually letting ourselves be controlled by powerful and clever forces to get us to consume,

[1615.1s - 1621.5s]: to be distracted, to be in a state of fear, and to measure status in terms of

[1622.0s - 1629.0s]: things that are not actually very satisfying. And so just to be aware of that

[1629.8s - 1637.7s]: gives you, inoculate you, against a lot of the things that keep us, you know, in a rat race or

[1637.7s - 1644.1s]: slaves to money. And I think that's the important thing. Now there's really good news, though,

[1644.3s - 1652.6s]: because remember our basic nature, what does make us satisfied, is to be self-transformed.

[1652.6s - 1661.1s]: And even if most people haven't cultivated it, they have that within them. And it is possible.

[1662.4s - 1675.2s]: And it's very important to realize then that ultimately, step by step, the generations are making

[1675.2s - 1683.5s]: changes. All parents realize that teenagers are very difficult often, because they have their own

[1683.5s - 1689.6s]: mind about what to value, and they're types of music and so on. But adolescence has a very

[1689.6s - 1699.1s]: interesting utility for the whole population of humanity, because the teenagers stop and reflect

[1699.1s - 1707.2s]: on what are the parents doing wrong. And they change a little, hopefully, in the right direction.

[1707.4s - 1712.7s]: Now all the parents' generation isn't necessarily going to agree with them. But what's happening is

[1712.7s - 1721.5s]: that we have, roughly speaking, there are three groups of personalities. The people who are

[1721.5s - 1727.6s]: dominated by their habit system and their desires. And we call those in terms of values,

[1727.6s - 1736.1s]: traditions, because they tend to be easily manipulated by fear and by people who promise to give them

[1736.1s - 1743.6s]: what they want. But they give up a lot of their capacity for self-regulation and freedom to people

[1743.6s - 1751.8s]: who they'll just more or less bluntly follow, dogmatic. There's another group of people that I think

[1751.8s - 1757.8s]: are dominant in terms of executive positions and business, but now those same business principles

[1757.8s - 1764.2s]: have permeated all of our social institutions. And things are generally driven by individual

[1764.2s - 1772.2s]: profit. And we've forgotten that when we gave corporations the rights of a person, initially they

[1772.2s - 1780.3s]: were also expected to have the duties of a person. But somehow somebody forgot about that, and it's

[1780.3s - 1787.0s]: not being enforced. And so you get this notion that a corporation only has responsibility to its

[1787.0s - 1794.8s]: investors and not to the community that's allowed it to operate. And so we have a lot of anti-social

[1796.7s - 1803.3s]: personalities that would be the diagnosis of most businesses these days. Now, there are good

[1803.3s - 1811.9s]: ones too that are just concerned about people and community responsibilities. But unfortunately,

[1812.7s - 1821.9s]: the neoliberal values that don't respect the reality of social justice that don't respect the

[1821.9s - 1827.4s]: need for sustainability and the way we care for our communities and our planet

[1828.8s - 1835.5s]: or not. We're not recognizing those responsibilities very effectively.

segments.text: Welcome to the Y on Earth Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry. And today,
we're visiting with Dr. Robert Klonenger. Hey Robert. Hey, good to see you here. Good to see you too.
I'm so excited about our conversation today and it's one that I think is
among the most important we can be having about our reaction and response to some of the great
challenges we're going through in these times. So I appreciate you taking the time to visit with us,
Dr. Robert Klonenger. Dr. Robert Klonenger is director of the Anthropedia Institute and Professor
of Maritus at Washington University in St. Louis. He was Wallace rendered professor of psychiatry,
Professor of genetics, Professor of psychological and brain sciences, and Director of the San
Zone Family Center for Wellbeing at Washington University School of Medicine until July 2019.
The Anthropedia Institute is the research and advisory component of the Anthropedia
Foundation, a nonprofit organization dedicated to development of human well-being through initiatives
and healthcare and education. He is widely cited and honored for his innovative biopsychosocial
research that spans the genetics, neurobiology, development, psychology, brain imaging, and assessment
of personality and psychopathology. His personality inventories have been used in more than 6,000
peer-reviewed publications around the world. And he is one of the most highly cited scientists
in the world across all fields, in fact in the top, one-one-hundredth of a percent.
He received his bachelor's with high honors and special honors in philosophy, psychology,
and anthropology from the University of Texas at Austin and received his MD from Washington University
and an honorary doctorate from the University of New Mea and the University of Gutenberg.
Dr. Klondinger has published 10 books and over 600 articles in psychiatry, psychology, and genetics.
